slides.title: Lesson 1: Introduction to Energy (Kinetic and Potential) - Part 1
slides.content:
Energy is the ability to do work or cause change. In mechanics, we focus on **kinetic energy** (energy of motion) and **potential energy** (stored energy due to position or configuration). All forms of energy are measured in **Joules (J)**, where $$1\,\text{J} = 1\,\text{kg}\cdot\text{m}^2/\text{s}^2.$$

**Kinetic Energy (K):**
$$K = \tfrac{1}{2} m v^2$$
- $$m$$: mass in kilograms (kg)
- $$v$$: speed in meters per second (m/s)

Example: A 2.0 kg cart moving at 3.0 m/s has kinetic energy $$K = \tfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(3.0)^2 = 9.0\,\text{J}.$$

**Gravitational Potential Energy near Earth (U_g):**
$$U_g = m g h$$
- $$g$$: gravitational field strength $$\approx 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$$
- $$h$$: height above a chosen reference level (m)

Choosing the reference level sets where $$U_g = 0.$$ Only **changes** in potential energy matter physically.

slides.title: Lesson 1: Introduction to Energy (Kinetic and Potential) - Part 2
slides.content:
**Mechanical Energy (E_{mech}):**
$$E_{\text{mech}} = K + U$$
This sums kinetic energy and potential energy for a system. In many problems, we also meet **elastic potential energy** stored in a spring:

**Elastic Potential Energy (U_s):**
$$U_s = \tfrac{1}{2} k x^2$$
- $$k$$: spring constant (N/m)
- $$x$$: stretch/compression from equilibrium (m)

Example: Lifting a 1.5 kg backpack to a shelf 2.0 m high increases its gravitational potential by $$\Delta U_g = (1.5)(9.8)(2.0) = 29.4\,\text{J}.$$ If you then let it slide down (no friction), that 29.4 J converts into kinetic energy at the bottom.

slides.title: Lesson 2: Work and Power - Part 1 (Work)
slides.content:
Work is the **energy transferred** to or from an object when a force causes a displacement. Only the component of the force **along the displacement** does work.

**Work for a constant force at an angle:**
$$W = F d \cos\theta$$
- $$F$$: force magnitude (N)
- $$d$$: displacement magnitude (m)
- $$\theta$$: angle between the force and displacement vectors

**Signs:**
- $$W > 0$$ when force has a component **in the same direction** as motion.
- $$W < 0$$ when force opposes motion (e.g., friction).

**Variable forces:** If $$F$$ changes with position, work is the **area under the $$F$$ vs. $$x$$ curve**:
$$W = \int_{x_i}^{x_f} F(x)\,dx$$
Example: Compressing a spring from $$x=0$$ to $$x=0.20\,\text{m}$$ with $$k=200\,\text{N/m}$$:
$$W = \tfrac{1}{2} k x^2 = \tfrac{1}{2}(200)(0.20)^2 = 4.0\,\text{J}.$$

slides.title: Lesson 2: Work and Power - Part 2 (Power)
slides.content:
Power is the **rate of doing work** or the **rate of energy transfer**.

**Average power:**
$$P_{\text{avg}} = \frac{W}{\Delta t}$$

**Instantaneous power:**
$$P = \frac{dW}{dt} = \vec{F}\cdot\vec{v}$$

**Units:** Power is measured in **Watts (W)**, where $$1\,\text{W} = 1\,\text{J/s}.$$

Example: You push a mower with a horizontal force of 120 N while it moves at 1.5 m/s. The instantaneous power is $$P = Fv = (120)(1.5) = 180\,\text{W}.$$

slides.title: Lesson 3: Conservation of Mechanical Energy - Part 1 (Work–Energy Theorem)
slides.content:
The **Work–Energy Theorem** connects force and energy:
$$W_{\text{net}} = \Delta K = K_f - K_i$$

Example: A 1000 kg car speeds up from 10 m/s to 20 m/s. The change in kinetic energy is:
$$\Delta K = \tfrac{1}{2} m (v_f^2 - v_i^2) = \tfrac{1}{2}(1000)(20^2 - 10^2) = 1.5\times10^5\,\text{J}.$$
So the net work on the car is $$1.5\times10^5\,\text{J}.$$

slides.title: Lesson 3: Conservation of Mechanical Energy - Part 2 (Conservative vs. Non-Conservative)
slides.content:
If **only conservative forces** (like gravity or ideal springs) do work, the **mechanical energy** of the system is constant:
$$K + U = \text{constant}$$
Equivalently,
$$K_i + U_i = K_f + U_f.$$

If **non-conservative forces** (like friction) do work:
$$W_{\text{nc}} = \Delta E_{\text{mech}} = (K_f + U_f) - (K_i + U_i).$$

Friction typically makes $$W_{\text{nc}} < 0$$, converting mechanical energy into thermal energy.

**Gravitational:** $$U_g = mgh$$.  **Spring:** $$U_s = \tfrac{1}{2}kx^2$$.

slides.title: Lesson 4: Efficiency
slides.content:
Efficiency tells us what fraction of the input energy becomes **useful** output energy (the rest often becomes heat, sound, etc).

**Efficiency (η):**
$$\eta = \frac{\text{Useful Energy Output}}{\text{Total Energy Input}} \times 100\%$$

Example: A device takes in 500 J of electrical energy and delivers 400 J of mechanical energy. The efficiency is $$\eta = (400/500)\times100\% = 80\%.$$

slides.title: Lesson 5: Introduction to Heat and Thermal Energy - Part 1
slides.content:
At the particle level, energy shows up as motion and interactions of atoms and molecules.

- **Thermal energy**: total microscopic kinetic energy of particles.
- **Temperature**: measures average kinetic energy per particle.
- **Heat (Q)**: energy transferred due to temperature difference.

Units: energy in Joules (J), temp in °C or K.

slides.title: Lesson 5: Introduction to Heat and Thermal Energy - Part 2 (First Law)
slides.content:
The **First Law of Thermodynamics**:
$$\Delta U = Q - W$$
- $$\Delta U$$: change in internal energy
- $$Q$$: heat added **to** the system
- $$W$$: work done **by** the system

Doing work reduces internal energy unless heat is added.

slides.question: Heat is?
options: Energy transferred due to temp difference
slides.answer: Energy transferred due to temp difference

slides.title: Lesson 6: Heat Exchange - Part 1 (Specific Heat)
slides.content:
When heat flows:
$$Q = m c \Delta T$$
- $$m$$: mass
- $$c$$: specific heat capacity
- $$\Delta T = T_f - T_i$$

Positive $$Q$$: gains heat; Negative $$Q$$: loses heat.

slides.title: Lesson 6: Heat Exchange - Part 2 (Calorimetry & Mixing)
slides.content:
In insulated systems:
$$\sum Q = 0$$

Two substances mixing to $$T_f$$:
$$m_1 c_1 (T_f - T_{1i}) + m_2 c_2 (T_f - T_{2i}) = 0.$$

slides.title: Lesson 7: Heating and Cooling Curves
slides.content:
- **Sloped segments:** $$Q = mc\Delta T$$
- **Flat segments:** $$Q = mL$$ (phase change)

Total for ice → steam:
$$Q = mc_{ice}\Delta T + mL_f + mc_{water}\Delta T + mL_v + mc_{steam}\Delta T.$$
